Keats’s letter continued. “For myself I know not how to express my devotion to so f a form: I want a brighter word than bright; a fairer word than fair.” Margaret and Samuel catch up with Fanny and collapse in t grass near her, watching her strange possession with the letter but knowing better than to interrupt. Keats’s letter continued. “I almost wish we were butterflies and liv’d but three su days --- three such days with you I could fill with more delight than fifty common years could ever contain.” Fanny beams at Margaret. She pulls her towards her and kisses her.  79 80 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 51.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: If I have ever been mean and I know I might have been, please forgive me my darling Toots. Margaret blinks with each kiss. FANNY (cont'd) Sorry, sorry, sorry. INT. FANNY’S BEDROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - NIGHT 79 Fanny prepares the paper by kissing it. My Dear Mr Keats, “Thank you for your letter. I have lately felt so nervous and ill that I had to stay days in bed. But having received your letter yesterday, I up and again walking our paths on the Heath. I have begun a butterfly farm in my bedroom in honour of Sammy and Toots are catching them for me. Samuel has made science of it and is collecting both caterpillars and chrysalises so we may have them fluttering about us a wee more.” The children and Fanny in the business of BUTTERFLY and CATERPILLAR collecting. JAR TOPS are covered in GREASE PROOF PAPER and tied aroun the top with STRING. The paper is PRICKED with a FORK for air holes. The jars are lined up around Fanny’s bedroom. Fanny's PEN DIPS into the INK, a BUTTERFLY in a GLASS COV JAR slowly CLOSES it’s wings as she writes her letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fanny talks to her mother in the kitchen. She is dressed an outing, all in WHITE, STRAW BONNET and WHITE PARASOL. Brawne is rolling out a PIE while the maid is IRONING.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: If a letter...

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: I promise I shall come and find you.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: But be ready. Have your hat and parasol ready.  81 82 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 52.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: Perhaps I'll send Abigail. Can you run?

dialogues.speaker: ABIGAIL
dialogues.text: Oh yes I can, if I lift my skirts go as fast as any boy or even a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fanny and Margaret are strolling near the POND where CHIL wade and coax their TOY BOATS along with a STICK. Samuel guiding his along from the edge. Fanny’s eyes scan any si of movement, a CHILD chasing a BALL, a MAN bowling a CRIC BALL, A MOTHER rushing after a TODDLER. Fanny lies on the GRASS face-down, dead-like. Most of the Heath’s revellers have left. Margaret sits near Fanny not knowing what to do. Samuel fiddles with his boat’s RIGGING.

dialogues.speaker: GROUND
dialogues.text: Shall we go home? Fanny? I have collected some leaves for the caterpillars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the staircase as Fanny enters lies a LETTER from Keats addressed to her. Fanny snatches up the letter and storms into the drawing room. Charles and Maria Dilke stand to greet her but she is in mid fury.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you send for me? Mr Keats has written and you did not send Abigail as you had said.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: Please greet our friends.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry but I cannot be polite when I have been so betrayed. Why are you against me Mama?

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: Fanny the letter could wait an hour. I needed Abigail.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Three hours!!!  83 84 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 53. Fanny storms out of the drawing room and upstairs to her room. The party downstairs re-seats themselves, the air fatally electrified around them.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA DILKE
dialogues.text: When did this happen?

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: Under my nose - I am praying to God it will blow over. INT. FANNY’S BEDROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - NIGHT 83 In the privacy of her room Fanny by CANDLELIGHT reads her letter. Keats’s letter. “I have two luxuries to brood over in my walks, your loveliness and the hour of my death. O that I could have possession of them both in the same minute. I am miserable that you are not with me: or rather breath in the dull sort of patience that cannot be called life. never knew before, what such a love as you have made me f was; I did not believe in it; my Fancy was afraid of it, it should burn me up. But if you will fully love me, thou there may be some fire it will not be more than we can be when moistened and bedewed with Pleasures.”

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: “Bedewed with Pleasures...” Fanny kisses the letter. INT. FANNY’S BEDROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - AFTERNOON 84 Mrs Brawne enters Fanny’s bedroom concerned by the romant chaos, BUTTERFLIES in the air, CLOTHES scattered about. Attempted LETTERS littering the bed and all about Fanny, KEATS'S LETTERS. Fanny looks up smiling.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: I forgive you Maman. Mrs Brawne OPENS a window.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: No Maman we will lose them.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: There is no air.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 54.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: They love the heat.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY, (READING)
dialogues.text: Listen, “I love you more in that I believe you have liked me for my own sake - I have met with women who I really think would like to be married to a poem and to be given away by a Novel.” “Married to a poem.” Fanny laughs amused. Mrs Brawne does not. Butterflies flutter past Mrs Brawne. FANNY (cont’d) Maman do not be cross. Fanny takes her mother’s hand. FANNY (cont'd) When I do not hear from him it is as if I have died, as if the air is sucked out of my lungs and I am left desolate, but when I receive a letter I know our world is real and it is the only one I care for. Mrs Brawne backs out of the door. Fanny gets up and follo Mrs Brawne to her own neat, clean bedroom. FANNY (cont’d) Was Mrs Dilke speaking against us?

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: She is your friend too. And she cares for and loves Mr Keats as I do.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: But not as I do. What did she say?

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: That he should not come back here and live is what Mrs Dilke said. What Mr Dilke is saying too.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: And you agree?

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Let me marry him Mama, if he comes back let us be.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: You ambush me Fanny.  85 86 87 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 55.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: I will organise my life. Take all the letters, you keep them, and once a day, no better, once a week you may give them to me for one hour. The rest of the week I shall work. I shall sew 4 hours, and study, and take up my dance classes, we can all walk upon the Heath. I will make you laugh again Mama but let us be engaged.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: No man wants to live off his wife’s family who are barely managing.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: You insult him and you insult me. Why must you do this? His great worth is in the future. What can we not afford, another chop? Then I shan’t eat and when I die the family can prosper, is this your logic? Mrs Brawne looks at Fanny hopelessly.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: Do your programme. Give me the letters, let us try.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: I may keep only the latest? Mama to have something of his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fanny, Margaret and Samuel are practising their dance ste Mrs Brawne passes through the room cautiously pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret and SIX OTHER CHILDREN receive instructions from Fanny on how to work a SWISS EMBROIDERY FRAME clamped to table.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY, (TO MARGARET)
dialogues.text: Fill the inside with as many padding stitches as you can, then use a wide slanted satin stitch. Mrs Brawne watches, cautiously pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret runs into the kitchen looking frightened. Mrs Brawne and Abigail are ROLLING PASTRY.  88 89 90 91 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 56.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Fanny wants a knife.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: What for? What has happened? Margaret's lip begins to quiver. Mrs Brawne runs up the kitchen stairs. INT. FANNY’S BEDROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - DAY 88 Fanny lies sobbing on the floor, clutching her latest let a TINY pair of SEWING SCISSORS lie nearby. The family cat sniffs curiously at her cheek, while only one live dazed BUTTERFLY flutters around the room. The CORPSES of many others lie about the floor and surfaces.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: It is all over. I have such a short letter, after all this time, saying he was in London, in London but couldn’t bring himself to visit for fear it would burn him up!

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: He wrote that, “burn him up?”

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: He has made no fortune and he is ashamed of it. If only he knew how little I, or even you, care for that now. I don’t know how I will live. Fanny breaks down, a small scratch on her wrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abigail and Margaret carry an armful of EMPTY butterfly J full of DEAD LEAVES downstairs to the kitchen. INT. FANNY’S BEDROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - EVENING 90 Fanny sweeps BUTTERFLY CORPSES into a dustpan. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. WENTWORTH HOUSE
dialogues.text: Margaret and Samuel are playing cricket in the garden, th stop and stare as Mr Brown appears on the path.

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: Hello.  92 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 57. Margaret turns and leaves immediately. Behind Mr Brown a THIN YOUNG MAN pulls a cart piled with Mr Brown’s holiday LUGGAGE. A crushed Fanny and Mrs Brawne are quietly sewing; Fanny DRESS, while Mrs Brawne DARNS. Margaret appears at the window.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Mr Brown has returned but no Mr Keats with my rocks he promised. Mrs Brawne looks across at Fanny anxiously.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: What can he do to me? Hurt my pride? It has slipped so low I have stepped out of it. INT. MR BROWN’S HALF WENTWORTH HOUSE - DAY 92 Mr Brown is surrounded by his LUGGAGE in piles in his dra room. He is PAYING the CARTER who puts the last of the ba down. There is a KNOCK at the door. Fanny enters followed by ABIGAIL their RED HEADED MAID, her head bowed.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Mama asked me to welcome you home and to introduce you to Miss O’Donaghue who is our maid but may also do for you. The young IRISH maid BLUSHES and CURTSEYS.

dialogues.speaker: ABIGAIL
dialogues.text: Please sir call me Abigail or Abby.

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: Very well. Be sure you do not enter when the door is closed. Abigail nods.

dialogues.speaker: ABIGAIL
dialogues.text: Yes sir. Abigail leaves. Mr Brown watches, his interest mildly aroused. Fanny remains awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: Mr Keats is not coming back. He is going to live in London.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Please tell Mr Keats that we Brawne’s have kept safe all his things.  93 94 95 96 97 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fanny takes the KEY from Keats’s chest stacked high with books. She threads it onto a RIBBON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fanny is KNITTING a fine wool SOCK in the DIMLY LIT kitch Abigail is kneading and making BREAD.

dialogues.speaker: ABIGAIL
dialogues.text: Mr Brown has said that I could learn to read yet and I said “what will I read?” And he said “even the Bible is not so dull as you might believe.” He has said that the “Songs of Solomon” are juicy enough to make a churchman blush and as I learn to read I will see he does not tell a lie! Fanny’s FOUR slim NEEDLES work steadily, systematically. Around her neck is the RIBBON reaching into her bodice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keats walks up the path to Wentworth House.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret runs into the room.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Mr Keats has come, aren’t you coming down? He needs the key to his chest. Fanny is startled. She puts down her NEEDLEWORK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fanny follows Margaret into the cellar where Keats and Sa are struggling with the LOCK.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: Do you have the key Fanny?

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Hello Mr Keats.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: Hello Miss Brawne.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 58A. The two stare at each other a long moment before Fanny removes the RIBBON from around her neck and gently pulls KEY clear from her bodice where it had been nestling in h bust. Fanny drops it into Keats’s hand.  98 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 59. Keats is transfixed by the warm KEY lying in his palm, burning it. Samuel leaves, his voice FADING off.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: Mama we have found it, Fanny had it like I thought. Ignoring everything but each other, Fanny gently takes th key from Keats and kneeling unlocks his CHEST. She opens lid.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: What do you need? Keats kneels beside her. He is unable to take his eyes fr her. He watches as Fanny pulls out items of clothing. FANNY (cont'd) Your coat? Fanny shakes it out holding it up. FANNY (cont’d) But it is not warm enough, there is no lining. These brown breeches are warm. Their eyes connect as Fanny turns slowly towards Keats th FOLDED PANTS in her hands. She turns back to the trunk. FANNY (cont'd) And your black vest, Ohhh it has a small hole. I could mend it so well you will not see it. Wordlessly Keats and Fanny continue bonding through the domestic chores simple and deep - all his resolve dissolv

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dilke family DINING ROOM where the Dilke’s SON and a FRIEND play. Charles Dilke writes at one end of the TABLE Keats at the other while Maria Dilke is POURING TEA. Keat PEN dips in his DARK BROWN INK. 11 & 13 October 1819 My Sweet Girl, “I am living today in yesterday: I was in a complete fascination all day. I feel myself at your mercy. Write m ever so few lines and tell me you will never for ever be less kind to me than yesterday - you dazzled me - there i nothing in the world so bright and delicate.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 59A. You have abosrbed me I have a sensation at the present mo as if I was dissolving ---”  99 100 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fanny and Keats walk slowly together through the AUTUMN LEAVES on the Heath. Samuel and Toots run ahead. The love lean together on the trunk of a huge ELM. Keats gives Fan a RING. Keats kisses Fanny deeply on the lips. Toots and Samuel shocked, stop in their tracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Brawne and Maria Dilke are talking gravely and taking in the Brawne’s dining room. Fanny passes through with he sewing.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: Fanny.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: What is wrong, you are looking so grave?

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: Maria says Mr Keats is now proposing to live next door again. She wants to know if I have any objections.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Of course you don’t. No she doesn’t. Mr Brown is Mr Keats’s best friend, how can we object. Maria Dilke is quiet, she looks at Mrs Brawne.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA DILKE
dialogues.text: Fanny, Mr Dilke and I are worried that such close connection may prove restrictive for you.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA DILKE
dialogues.text: I don’t think you fully understand. Mr Keats can’t afford to marry, his circumstances are really quite hopeless and if he is next door how will you meet anyone else? How will you go to dances? Mrs Dilke notices Fanny’s ring, shocked. MARIA DILKE (cont'd) Ohh but you are engaged?

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: It was Mr Keat’s mothers ring, not an engagement ring.  101 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 61.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE, (OVERLAPPING)
dialogues.text: You were not to wear it

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: See I wear it on the finger next door

dialogues.speaker: MARIA DILKE
dialogues.text: What a pretty ring.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: Do not even discuss it. She is in no way bound to him. Mrs Brawne is SHAKING her head exhausted by Fanny’s power persuasion.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You taught me to love, you never said only the rich, only a thimbleful. Mr Keats is a genius. His poems will sell, and until then I could make money sewing.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA DILKE
dialogues.text: Attachment is such a difficult thing to undo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fanny is walking towards Keats and Mr Brown’s door. She slips her GARNET RING off her middle finger and across to engagement finger.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: Fanny! Fanny hides her left hand behind her back.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: I am going to say good morning.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: How will he write his poems if you are with him? Come.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: It is alright he is simply fair copying the poems for a new book and in this I give him calm. Fanny enters the poets rooms almost invisibly. Quietly sh takes a CHAIR and places it next to Keats at the table. S begins to sew. Mr Brown, at the other end of the table, finally notices and leaves perturbed. As the door closes Fanny and Keats immediately begin to kiss. Keats rests hi head on Fanny’s chest.  102 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 62.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: “Pillow’d upon my fair love’s ripening breast, To feel forever it’s soft swell and fall, Awake forever in a sweet unrest Still, still to hear her tender taken breath.”

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: It’s new, from which poem?

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: Yours - “Bright Star would I were stedfast as thou art- Not in lone splendour hung aloft the night.”

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Why do you say Not? Not in lone splendour?

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: Because I want to be close enough to you, (kiss), to hear your every breath, (kiss), yet I wish for the eternal faithfulness of a star.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY, (PUSHING HIM BACK)
dialogues.text: You fear I am not steadfast because I oblige Maman by going to a dance?

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: Don’t tease Fanny.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: I will tell Maman I am unwell. Fanny kisses Keats.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: No, go, go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Brown scoffs FRESH SCONES in the kitchen. Abigail BUTT them for him full of admiration. Fanny is working on her SCRAPBOOK of fashion ideas.

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: Good Irish Abigail Who never did fail To make a scone As good as a swan... Abigail puts a hand over her rotted teeth as she giggles. Suddenly Fanny rises, she is looking out the window as th SNOW begins to fall. Fanny leaves the room.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 63.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Brawne sees Fanny walking out into the snow. She move to the window.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: Fanny come in, it has turned very cold.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Mr Keats has gone into London with no coat. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SNOW has turned to SLEET. The Brawne’s make their way CANDLE up to their rooms. 105 INT. FANNY’S BEDROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - NIGHT 105 Fanny watches from her window. RAIN is reflected across h face. She is relieved to finally see the small chilled figure of Keats making his way unsteadily to the house. 106 INT. MR BROWN’S HALL WENTWORTH HOUSE - NIGHT 106 Mr Brown comes out from his study as he hears the front d CLOSE. Keats is WET and staggering, finding it hard to stand.

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: Have you had wine? Keats shakes his head. MR BROWN (cont'd) What is the matter, are you fevered?

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: Yes, yes. I was severely chilled. I was on the outside of the coach - but now I don’t feel it. 107 INT. FANNY’S BEDROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - NIGHT 107 It is PITCH BLACK only the SOUND of Mr Brown’s VOICE SHOUTING, BANGING and FOOTSTEPS.

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN, (VOICE OFF)
dialogues.text: Abigail! Abigail! Get up, dress yourself we need a doctor.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 63A. Fanny sits up terrified.  108 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fanny in her DRESSING GOWN and with a CANDLE. Abigail is carrying SHEETS through to the laundry. Fanny follows her

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: What has happened?

dialogues.speaker: ABIGAIL
dialogues.text: I don’t know Ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Has a doctor arrived?

dialogues.speaker: ABIGAIL
dialogues.text: Yes Ma’am. Mr Brown told me to take these sheets off as they are bloodied. Abigail places them in the LAUNDRY TUB and turns on the WATER.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Is it Mr Keats? Abigail makes her way back to the STOVE with its BOILING KETTLE.

dialogues.speaker: ABIGAIL
dialogues.text: I don’t know Ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Let me help. Fanny puts CHINA CUPS on a TRAY. Her hands are shaking. M Brown comes through. Fanny moves towards him about to spe

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN ECHOING, (INTERRUPTING)
dialogues.text: Not now Fanny, I can’t talk.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: If he’s ill I want to help. He would want me there.

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: Move away, this is an emergency. A basin, I need a basin and a towel, glasses.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: I can bring them.

dialogues.speaker: NO
dialogues.text: Fanny stands back offering no resentment. The SOUND of WA filling the wash tub sends her to the laundry. She turns the TAP, Keats’s BLOODIED SHEETS blooming in the dark tub  109 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Brown is standing by the kitchen HEARTH, towels are fo on the table. Abigail crosses past with a barely touched TRAY of BROTH and TOAST from Keats’s room. DR BREE is finishing up a plate of bacon and eggs. The Brawnes (including Samuel and Margaret) are sitting at the table listening anxiously.

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: Doctor Bree was particular in saying that Mr Keats should avoid all sources of excitement. It is a disease peculiarly vulnerable to romantic anxiety. Brown looks towards the Doctor who confirms Brown’s explanation with a nod.

dialogues.speaker: DR BREE
dialogues.text: A lot of rest. He leaves, head down, signalling them to remain.

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: Keats has already asked to see Miss Brawne but I have managed him and said she had gone into town...

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: But I have not. How could I go into town when Mr Keats is so ill?

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: I am speaking of keeping Mr Keats calm.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: What must he be thinking? This is a deception I cannot join.

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: It is not a deception, I am simply determined to preserve the life of my friend.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: He will be unquiet until he sees me...

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: He has been profoundly unquiet since you have decided to love him Miss Brawne.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: He would be more unquiet if I decided not to.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE, (SHARPLY)
dialogues.text: Fanny!  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 65A.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Mr Brown would have it that I kill Mr Keats with affection.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 66.

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: Perhaps you will. Perhaps there is nothing I can do to protect him from your insistence of loving him into an early grave. But I shall try, Miss Brawne, I shall try! All visits will follow my regime or they will not happen at all. Fanny sits back shocked.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: Please, we Brawne’s will do whatever we can to restore Mr Keats to health. INT. KEATS’S ROOM/PASSAGE WENTWORTH HOUSE - EVENING 110 Fanny waits outside Keats’s room. She puts her GARNET RIN onto her engagement finger. The DOOR opens, Mr Brown stan aside to allow Fanny through.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: Darling girl. I have been wondering where you were.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: I never did go to town, I have been waiting to be with you the whole day.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: Last night there was a great rush of blood, such that I thought I cannot survive, that I would suffocate. I said to Mr Brown very calmly “this is unfortunate” and my thoughts were of you. Keats strokes her hand. KEATS (cont'd) Knowing you are next door makes a pleasant prison of my house. Mr Brown enters the room and Fanny immediately lets go of Keats's hand and rises. KEATS (cont'd) Come as frequently as they allow. And write me when you cannot. INT. STAIRS/MRS BRAWNE’S ROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - NIGHT 111 Fanny runs upstairs into her mother’s room. Mrs Brawne ta her in her arms, Fanny SOBS onto her lap.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 67.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: He has a new greatcoat, why didn’t he wear it? Oh God, Oh God he spat so much blood. Why must this happen to us? I am so afraid. Fanny abruptly sits up wiping her face. FANNY (cont ’d) Wait, I have to write him a note so he has something of me tomorrow morning.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “My sweet creature when I look back upon the ecstasies in which I have pass’d some days and the miseries in their turn, I wonder the more at the Beauty which has kept up the spell so fervently. When I send this round I shall be in the front parlour watching to see you show yourself for a minute in the garden. How horrid was the chance of slipping into the ground instead of into your arms - the difference is amazing Love. Do not take the trouble of writing much: merely send me my “good night,” to put under my pillow.” J. Keats Keats is resting in a MAKESHIFT BED made from chairs. Fan appears in the garden, Keats’s NOTE in her hand. She walk towards Keats’s window. Mr Brown looks up from his desk. He gets up and walks towards the windows.

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN, (SHOOING FANNY)
dialogues.text: Go! Go on! Keats turns to see Fanny.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: No Brown I need to see her. Fanny KISSES her NOTE and holds it to her heart. Keats smiles at her. KEATS (cont'd) I feel anxious if I miss a day.

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: Why not bed her, she would do whatever you wished. It might relieve your condition. Keats is writing a LETTER. On his SIDEBOARD is a row of J and JELLIES, GIFTS from friends’ larders.  120 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 69. INT. FANNY’S BEDROOM - DAY 115 Fanny sits on the edge of her bed and writes on a SMALL P OF PAPER the words “good night”. INT. DOORWAY TO MR BROWN’S APARTMENT - DAY 116 The FOLDED PAPER with “Mr Keats” written in tiny handwrit is slipped under Mr Brown and Keats’s door. Both men turn look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BARE CHESTED Keats takes the NOTE from his trouser pock unfolds it, puts it to his lips then places it under his PILLOW. He RAPS on the wall. INT. FANNY’S BEDROOM - EVENING 118 The “rap” is faint on Fanny’s side but she hears it and p her hand against her side of the wall. Toots already in b watches the ritual. Fanny’s SHADOW FLICKERS large against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fanny sits upon a STONE WALL on Hampstead Heath reading h note while Samuel and Margaret play with a CRICKET BALL. Fanny walks, still reading through some desolate SKELETON TREES, NO LEAVES above and MUD below. “Let me no longer detain you from going to Town - there m be no end to this emprisoning of you. Perhaps you had bet not come before tomorrow evening: send me however without fail a good night. You know our situation - I am recommen not even to read poetry much less write it. I wish I had even a little hope. I cannot say forget me - but I would mention that there are impossibilities in the world.” Your affectionate J.K.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 120
dialogues.text: 121 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 70. INT. HALL/MR BROWN’S DRAWING ROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - DAY 1 Fanny walks quickly to Mr Brown’s half of the house where Keats is propped up on a DAY BED. She draws a chair next him. Fanny sews and talks quietly.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Why do you say impossibilities?

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: I have coughed blood again. I fear the disease has the upper hand and I cannot recover.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: I cannot leave you. It is an impossibility. I have such clear hope about your new book of poems. When you are well enough you can finish the fair copying. They are more beautiful than any I have read of Mr Coleridge or Mr Wordsworth or even Lord Byron. FANNY (cont'd) “Oh What can ail thee knight at arms, Alone and palely loitering? The sedge has withered from the lake And no birds sing!” FANNY (cont’d) “I met a lady in the Meads Full beautiful, a faery’s child; Her hair was long, her foot was light And her eyes were wild -”

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: “I set her on my pacing steed And nothing else saw all day long, For sidelong would she bend, and sing A faery’s song -”

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: “She found me roots of relish sweet And honey wild and manna dew, And sure in language strange she said I love thee true -”  122 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 71.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: “She took me to her elfin grot And there she wept and sigh’d full sore, And there I shut her wild wild eyes With kisses four.”

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: “And there she lulled me asleep And there I dream’d - Ah! Woe betide! The latest dream I ever dreamt On the cold hill side.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fanny comes into the kitchen where Abigail is making an incredible RACKET, BANGING POTS, and STOMPING to and fro. On the TABLE is a LETTER.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Is it mine?

dialogues.speaker: ABIGAIL
dialogues.text: Aye it is. Mr Brown has said to give it to you tomorrow, but I shall not wait. He is every bit as cruel as any gaoler of any prison in this foul world. Let him do his own dirty work. Fanny takes up the LETTER. She looks at Abigail and sees eyes are red from crying. ABIGAIL (cont'd) If you have a note for poor Mr Keats I will take it as soon as you will. Abigail bursts into TEARS. Fanny moves to comfort her. ABIGAIL (cont'd) I wish I were dead. Oh my God! Ohhh! Ohhh!  123 124 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 72. INT. FANNY’S BEDROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - DAY 123 Fanny writes at her PORTMANTEAUX. Dearest Love, “I hope you rested well last night. I am turning circles joy that you have finished the fair copy of your book. Did you hear from your side the banging of pots? Abigail been sobbing without stop and believes you are the only o she can confess her troubles to. I shall send you later your “good night” with Abigail. Sh has quite changed and will help me whenever I ask!” Yours ever and with love Fanny “P.S. Tell me as soon as you are able when Dr Bree has co and what he says.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keats turns as Mr Brown enters.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: I am boiling with fury.

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: What is it? This is not good, be calm. You must not convulse again.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: Abigail is with child, but to whom out of shame or fear she would not say. We Brown must find out and when we have his name, butcher or baker, he shall face up to his indecency. Call her, let us get it done..

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: It’s not necessary. She has me believe I am the father.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: My God, I had no notion of a love affair.

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: There was none or I must have slept through it. I woke up after some claret to find the girl in my bed snoring like a fireman.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: With what ease you help yourself.  125 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 73.

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: It was an accident. Now she is starting a sobbing campaign to marry me. I shan’t of course.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: And the child?

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: I have agreed to pay expenses. The worst thing is I can’t keep this place, I have to start my summer rental early. I feel wretched turning you out while you are unwell, but I haven’t anything left, only debt.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: Don’t be concerned, I shall manage. In what stumbling ways a new soul is begun. INT. BROWN’S DRAWING ROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - DAY Fanny quietly pours tea and moves softly amongst Keats's LITERARY SUPPORTERS and Dr Bree. She is invisible to all Keats who constantly watches her.

dialogues.speaker: MR HUNT
dialogues.text: Gentleman I think we should hear Dr. Bree on the issue of climate for Keats health. Does he want to go to Rome?

dialogues.speaker: DR BREE
dialogues.text: He has to go. He won't live through another winter in England.

dialogues.speaker: MR HUNT
dialogues.text: How do you feel about Italy John? Keats doesn’t reply

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: I think it’s an issue of finance.

dialogues.speaker: MR HUNT
dialogues.text: Could we between us not start a fund or a collection? Where are we up to with the poems?

dialogues.speaker: MR HASLAM
dialogues.text: We have them in the Galley now.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN REYNOLDS
dialogues.text: Could they not generate income?

dialogues.speaker: MR HASLAM
dialogues.text: It is very hard to predict sales + eH  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 73A.

dialogues.speaker: MR HUNT
dialogues.text: Of course he'll need a traveling companion. Brown, you’ll go?

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: Yes, absolutely someone must go, but I’m not sure I’1l be able to.

dialogues.speaker: MR HUNT
dialogues.text: Is that a ‘No’?

dialogues.speaker: DR BREE
dialogues.text: There is an excellent English doctor in Rome, a Dr Clark, who could also find rooms for you Mr Keats.  126 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 74.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS, (TURNING FROM FANNY)
dialogues.text: Pardon?

dialogues.speaker: DR BREE
dialogues.text: I am talking of a Dr Clark who attends the English colony in Rome.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: MR HUNT
dialogues.text: I can help find a room for the summer John if you want. At that moment a pregnant Abigail makes her way into the with a tray of hot tea. (OVERLAPPING)

dialogues.speaker: ABIGAIL, (HISSING)
dialogues.text: Miss, Miss. But it is Mr Brown who strides irritated to the door and swiftly takes the hot pot. Abigail doesn’t move, she stay still like a stunned rabbit. The men look then look away discretely.

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: Which poem goes first? Is it to be Lamia or Eve of St Agnes?

dialogues.speaker: MR HASLAM
dialogues.text: It is Lamia I believe. Keats nods once again watching Fanny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All along the street are signs of the precarious life of poor, STREET URCHINS begging, a DRUNK collapsed in the pavement. Fanny and Samuel support Keats along the road, pausing as a cough racks his body. Samuel walks a few steps behind, next to a BOY carting Keats’s TRUNK.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: I want to come to Italy with you. We can marry and I’1l go with you. Sammy walk behind. Keats laughs.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: My friends talk of Italy but I have no money and must yet make it through the summer in London. Besides, I don’t believe it possible I could ever leave you. Samuel is slinking up alongside Fanny and Keats.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY, (EXASPERATED)
dialogues.text: Get back behind.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: Poor Sammy, he’s not a dog.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: But he will tell!

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: I won't tell.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: You see, he listens. Keats stops.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS, (EVASIVE)
dialogues.text: Farewell me here.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fanny and Keats follow the LANDLADY down a DAMP corridor a BASEMENT SUITE of TWO WATER STAINED ROOMS. There is a TABLE DIMLY LIT by the basement’s WINDOW. A SHRIEK follow by another somewhere higher in the building.

dialogues.speaker: LANDLADY
dialogues.text: We don’t do linen. She leaves, SHOUTING back up the stairs. Keats sits at the DESK. He pretends to write. He turns to see Fanny’s look of horror. Keats looks away, shamed, steely.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Mr Hunt cannot have meant these rooms. Keats is going darkly into himself. He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: I told you not to come. Tell me how will you fill your days when we are apart? Who will you find to smile with?  128 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 76.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: No one, I will wait.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: Wait? Fanny nods, confused. KEATS (cont'd) Yes you can wait, you can probably find amusements. I am not the same as you. The very air I breathe empty of you is unhealthy. You are to me an object intensely desirable. But that’s all right because you can wait! You don’t know what it is to love. It is making me glad there is such a thing as the grave!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fanny, her mother, Samuel and Margaret and the Dilke’s ar sitting at their FORMALLY SET TABLE. All are very subdued Fanny is deeply depressed. Out of nowhere she starts to s The children and Mrs Brawne watch her anxiously. All deco is swept aside as Fanny’s sobs become convulsive. Mrs Bra waves the children away. She takes Fanny’s head in her ar stroking her tears away but they do not stop. Mrs Dilke a strokes her.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: He wrote that I don’t love him. He was told I have been flirting...but I haven't.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA DILKE
dialogues.text: How long has Mr Keats been gone?

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: Five weeks.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA DILKE
dialogues.text: Perhaps it is for the best.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Whose best?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA DILKE
dialogues.text: I thought it might be a relief to be separated when the circumstances are so difficult.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Everyone wishes I would give up, but I cannot, even if I wanted to I cannot. There is no one in this world so beautiful or so brilliant.  129 130 131 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 77. Mrs Dilke and Mrs Brawne exchange looks of anxiety. Toots face appears at the window. FANNY (cont'd) Get rid of her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret is outside in the garden PICKING FLOWERS when sh notices something strange under the HEDGE. A LEG, then as she cautiously circles, ANOTHER LEG and a BUNDLE beside i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fanny approaches the tree slowly like a cat until a very Keats, barely recognisable, turns, his eyes accusing and frightened on Fanny. Keats puts an arm out to fend Fanny off.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: Keep away if you do not love me, if you have not a crystal conscience this past month.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: John...? Fanny does not hesitate, she kisses Keats. He is sheet wh and sweating.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: I thought my heart was breaking.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: You are shivering. What is this, blood? Maman! Toots, call Maman.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: Hunt’s son opened your letter and hid it for two days...I’ve walked out, I’ve left them... (KEATS IS BARELY ABLE TO SPEAK)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keats falls to one side unconscious as Mrs Brawne arrives outside.  132 133 134 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 78.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. GARDENS/HALL WENTWORTH HOUSE
dialogues.text: The Brawnes assist Keats towards the house The Brawne’s roll Keats gently onto a SHEET and together him upstairs and onto Mrs Brawne’s BED. INT. MRS BRAWNE’S BEDROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - DAY 133 Doctor Bree is applying SUCTION GLASSES to Keats’s back. Fanny sits beside him stroking his forehead. Mrs Brawne picks up Keats’s SOILED CLOTHES from the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Brawne is putting Keats’s clothes into the TUB. Fanny joins her helping to scrub the stains.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Maman may Mr Keats stay?

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: Yes all right, tonight.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: And tomorrow? Until he leaves for Italy?

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: But you are not even officially engaged.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Can’t we be?

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: Please do not begin, there is no end to this, next you will want to marry and after that travel to Rome. It is all my doing. I should never have moved to this house. I have let this happen.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Let him stay just until Italy. I promise I shall never ever ask anything more. You will not regret it. Mrs Brawne continues to scrub.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: You are already the source of so much gossip.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Well let us be engaged. He is too ill to bea threat!  135 136 137 138 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 79. INT. MRS BRAWNE’S BEDROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - NIGHT 135 Fanny sits beside her feverish fiance, cooling his head w a WET CLOTH. She moves her ENGAGEMENT RING across to the fourth finger on her left hand. Her RING SPARKLES in the night. Bright Star.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VEGETABLES are being peeled and chopped. A CHICKEN BROTH strained.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 137
dialogues.text: INT. MRS BRAWNE’S BEDROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - DAY 138 Inside Keats is dressed, lying dreaming on a DAY BED by t window. Fanny takes the tray and puts it carefully on Keats’s lap Margaret steps shyly towards Keats smiling.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: Toots have you been eating rosebuds?

dialogues.speaker: TOOTS
dialogues.text: No, I never have.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: So where do your cheeks get their blush? Fanny pulls her chair close, signalling Margaret to leave

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Bye, bye. Keats begins to sip the SOUP. There is a WILD ROSE on Keats's tray. Fanny takes a PETAL and winds it around her finger.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: “fold a rose leaf around thy finger’s taperdness, And soothe thy lips.” Fanny rubs the PETAL across her lips.  139 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 80. KEATS (cont'd) ...sometimes remember that I did not only dote on roses but climbed mountains and cut up bodies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a small gathering of Keats’s inner circle in the Brawne living room. MR TAYLOR and MR HASLAM Keats's publishers, Mr Severn a young and very nervous painter fr and MR HUNT a loyal supporter. The tea has mostly been dr and people are preparing to leave. Fanny is quietly sewing a silk lining onto a CAP. An improving Keats sits next to her. They are very much a couple.

dialogues.speaker: MR TAYLOR
dialogues.text: I confirmed your ship, the Maria Crowther sailing to Naples.

dialogues.speaker: MR SEVERN
dialogues.text: When does she leave?

dialogues.speaker: MR HASLAM
dialogues.text: In ten days. Keats winces, he looks at Fanny stops sewing, stops breathing.

dialogues.speaker: MR TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Autumn is coming, it’s getting colder, I’m afraid if you delay there will be less and less reason to hope.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: So there is no putting it off I must march against the battery. Mr Severn has SPILT his TEA onto his SAUCER and is neurotically dallying about what to do.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Let me pour you another.

dialogues.speaker: MR SEVERN
dialogues.text: Really, well perhaps I might just tip it back, no well perhaps not. Did I take sugar?

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Yes I think you did.

dialogues.speaker: MR SEVERN
dialogues.text: Well then I did not stir it.  140 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 81.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Mr Keats tells me you are planning to paint in Rome...

dialogues.speaker: MR SEVERN, (DISTRACTED)
dialogues.text: We shall be in need of an Italian dictionary Mr Keats. Sorry, yes indeed I shall definitely paint. Shaking hands with Keats Mr Severn leaves. Mr Haslam says his farewell to Keats.

dialogues.speaker: MR HASLAM, (DISCREETLY)
dialogues.text: Mr Brown could not go?

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: Sadly not! I am waiting to hear but I think it not likely. Mr Haslam nods a moment thinking.

dialogues.speaker: MR HASLAM
dialogues.text: Well there is no alternative, we must put all our hope and faith in Mr Severn. A distressed Fanny continues the TINY, PERFECT STITCHES around Keats’s CAP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fanny is putting a TRAY together for her and Keats’s supp Mrs Brawne is SHELLING PEAS.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: My God what I would do to accompany him. He is still so weak.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: No. No! I have looked into it, we can’t afford the fare and if anything should happen to Mr Keats or even you in a foreign country, how could you survive?  141 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 82.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: But it should not be Mr Severn he barely knows him. Where is that fool Mr Brown when he is needed? Why doesn’t he write? Fanny picks up the tray.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: I have found a goose for Mr Keats’s last dinner.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY, (SUDDENLY TERRIFIED)
dialogues.text: Do not say “last”.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fanny puts Keats’s arm in the correct position about her waist for a waltz. She is giggling, shaking her head happily. Beside her Margaret and Samuel stand ready excep Margaret is laughing at Keats who is clowning in his effo The dance class is happening on the lawn in the BACK GARD It’s late afternoon and the trees are casting beautiful SHADOWS across the GRASS, while the ROSES bob in the bree Mrs Brawne is at the open windows.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: Ready?

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Yes, please. Mrs Brawne sits back at the PIANO and begins. FANNY (cont’d) One, two, three, turn...

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: Two or three Posies With two or three simples - Two or three Noses With two or three pimples - Margaret and Samuel are laughing too much to keep dancing Keats is making up his own mad steps. Fanny is nimbly keeping up. KEATS (cont'd) What? Two of three Wiggles With two or three Giggles. Keats stops beside an AUTUMN LEAF. KEATS (cont'd) What’s that?  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 82A. Fanny playfully stands on it.  142 143 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 83.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Nothing whatsoever. There is no autumn in this house only summer. Please remove it. Margaret takes the LEAF by the stork like a mouse by the and drops it over the fence.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: And don’t come back. Keats and Fanny dance on in their own gay way until Keats stops and lies in the grass catching his breath. He looks and sees the AUTUMN TREE TOPS. INT. MRS BRAWNE’S BEDROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - DAY 142 Fanny is arranging Keats’s CLOTHES in his TRUNK. Keats is the LITTLE DESK writing in the front piece of his RED BOU POETRY BOOKS. Fanny sits back and watches him, drinking up the last mom of his presence as if he were the sun setting. Fanny move across and gently strokes Keats’s head and he, like a cat plays up to the stroking, moving his head under her palm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family are eating a roast goose together. The plates still full, but no-one except Samuel is eating. Fanny sta to gather the plates up. Keats brings from the SIDEBOARD RED BOUND POETRY BOOKS and puts one beside each family member. Mrs Brawne is looking at hers.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: Oh my mad boy, it is so beautiful. Was ita success?

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: There are two highly positive reviews, by friends, six mainly positive and four hostile. I don’t know, is that successful?

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Yes! Extremely so...

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: So they are selling well?

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Why must you harp on about selling when the poems themselves are the point and they are so beautiful! Margaret and Samuel each give Keats a GIFT, Margaret a HANDKERCHIEF she has sewn.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 84.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: Yes of course they are, come back and live with us, marry our Fanny, I will miss you as a son.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (HUGGING KEATS)
dialogues.text: I love you. She gives Keats a tearful, clinging hug. Fanny puts the HAT she has been sewing on Keats's head.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: It’s your old travel cap. I have sewn a silk lining to keep you warm. 144 INT. MRS BRAWNE’S BEDROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - NIGHT 144 Fanny clips a LOCK of Keats’s hair and carefully folds it into a piece of TISSUE PAPER. Keats picks up the SCISSORS

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Is this really happening? Are we really to separate? Keats selects a DARK CURL from Fanny and cuts it. He puts between the pages of his POETRY BOOK.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: I sha’nt be able to speak tomorrow, I suspect I will break down. Let us say our goodbyes now.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: I want to come to Italy with you.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: And then...?

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Be together.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: For how long?

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: As long as we have. Keats sighs. Fanny begins to cry. FANNY (cont'd) Shall we awake and find all this is a dream? Is there another life? There must be, we cannot be created for this kind of suffering.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 84A. Keats puts his arms around Fanny’s neck and draws her hea him. Keats soothes her while he talks.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 85.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: I doubt we shall see each other again on this earth.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Then why are you leaving? Why must you go?

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: Because my friends insist on torturing me with a hope they can ill afford but have already financed. It is a hopeless hope, but how do I refuse?

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Say you are too ill.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: “More happy love! More happy, happy love! For ever warm and still to be enjoyed, For ever panting and for ever young.” We have woven a web you and I, attached to the world but a new world of our own invention. We must cut the threads Fanny. Fanny shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: No. I can’t, I never will. Keats moves away, hitting his head with his palm.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: Who do I fool? Do I wish you free? NO! NO! My still unravished bride, I should have bed you while I was well enough, why not? It could have been us with child not Brown with his bastard.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: You know I would do anything...

dialogues.speaker: KEATS, (BITTERLY)
dialogues.text: I have a conscience! Keats is walking to calm himself in his agony. KEATS (cont'd) Then let us pretend I am returning in Spring? Fanny looks up slowly.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: You will return, I know it.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: Will we live in the country?  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 86.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Yes, close to Maman.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: Our bedroom will look out on an apple orchard and beyond that a mountain. I am most partial to a mountain in a mist.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: I will make a garden where every sort of wild flower grows. We can take our breakfast there on a little table.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: We will go to bed while the sun is still high.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Then it will get dark and the moon will shine through the shutters.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: And I will hold you close and kiss your breasts, your waist, your arms.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Everywhere. Keats kisses Fanny’s breasts, waist and her arms, then ru his hands along her hands until their fingers touch.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: Touch has a memory.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: I know it... Outside is the sound of FOOTSTEPS.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: Your mother?

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: She won’t come in.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: Fanny. I am going to bed.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: I am just joining you.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: And we will never separate.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Never. Not for one night. Fanny and Keats hold tightly on to each other.  145 146 147 148 149 150 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 87. INT. MRS BRAWNE’S BEDROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - MORNING 145 Keats stands dressed, ready to leave. The trunk has gone. But still he stays, looking for the last time at the room which he has enjoyed some happiness. The will to go seems impossible to summon, but finally a rattling cough breaks his reverie. Fanny comes to fetch him.

dialogues.speaker: KEATS
dialogues.text: Not a word. Fanny nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fanny and Keats leave the house silently. Margaret runs after them. Fanny turns and desperately sha her head dissuading her from coming further. Margaret fal back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fanny and Keats arm in arm keep stride down the narrow la towards the Pond Street Coach Depot. Fanny looks towards Keats but does not speak. Mr Hunt walks a little apart anxiously aware of the young couples ordeal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amidst the SMALL CROWD at the COACH DEPOT, STABLE HANDS, CLEANERS, OTHER TRAVELLERS arriving and PARCELS and PRODU being unpacked and stacked, Keats and Fanny remain poised Finally without speaking Keats disengages his arm and squeezes Fanny’s hand. He swiftly boards the COACH. Fanny watches as he is seated then turns and leaves. Keats look out at the last of Fanny’s figure walking away. Mr Hunt climbs in beside Keats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fanny bursts through the door of Wentworth House. She run up the stairs into her room. Fanny opens the LITERARY POC BOOK Keats gave her and writes, “MR KEATS LEFT HAMPSTEAD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TREES on the Heath are almost bare and the sky is a D GREY. PILES OF AUTUMN LEAVES are BURNING, smoking the tre  151 152 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 88.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. BRAWNE DINING ROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE
dialogues.text: A SINGLE BLACK THREAD noses it’s way through the eye of a NEEDLE. The needle threads in and out of the BLACK MATERI Fanny is sewing. Mrs Brawne sits nearby mending. Margaret is running across the drawing room windows as Mr Brown followed by Abigail their BABY and their LUGGAGE ar back at Wentworth House.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: The baby! Abigail’s baby! Oh God it has red hair!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abigail now Mrs Brown, is taking tea in the dining room a happily showing off her baby boy to Mrs Brawne and Margar In the connecting sitting room Mr Brown stands at the win shuffling through his LETTERS from Keats, making an effor engage with Fanny who is clearly resistant. Fanny is sewi a length of BLACK RIBBON onto the black material, one nea small black stitch after another.

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: You saw the baby? Looks like Abigail...John’s reached Naples. They quarantined his ship. He wrote that he made more puns in two weeks out of desperation than he had in any other year of his life. I should have liked to have heard them.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: You could have, had you gone - I was certain you would.

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: I’m planning daily but I fear I have left it too late.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Why not leave now, travel overland? Abigail walks smilingly into the room holding out the cry baby to show Fanny. Mr Brown waves Abigail and the baby away.

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: It’s not simple with the baby and my funds reduced, then there’s the snows...

dialogues.speaker: IMPRESSION
dialogues.text: And lack of will.  153 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 89.

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: Should I say it aloud? Will that satisfy you? I have failed John Keats - I have failed him. And I pay a price daily - I did not know till now how tightly he had wound himself about my heart.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: What heart? You abandon your ill friend, never replying or enquiring.

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: Fortunately in my absence he was not short of care, his letter was full of your family’s kindness...

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: And my love. Mr Brown is a little stunned, moved despite himself by he open confession.

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN, (LEAVING)
dialogues.text: He asked me to offer whatever comfort can be given to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fanny sews a seam in BLACK THREAD. Outside it is SNOWING. The DOOR BELL RINGS. Margaret answers. It is a LETTER. Sh puts it on the other end of the table.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: For you Maman, it’s from Italy. Fanny stops sewing, alarmed. Mrs Brawne slowly rises and walks to the letter. She glances at Fanny who is waiting fearfully. Mrs Brawne opens the letter.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: It’s from Keats in Naples. He says it looks like a dream. Mrs Brawne stops reading and looks at Fanny who shakes he head with relief and disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Why doesn’t he write to me? Fanny looks out into the garden where a bowed Brown reads letter.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 89A. 154 INT/EXT. BROWN’S LIVING ROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - DAY 15 Mr Brown stands at his window, looking out onto a dreary WINTER GARDEN.  155 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 90. He watches as Margaret and Samuel kick a BALL between the and beyond them the gaunt, upright figure of Fanny slowly comes into view. A mirror match in mood to himself, she paces ghostlike in the snow. Fanny and Brown lock eyes th each look away. INT. BROWN’S DRAWING ROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - DAY 155 Fanny knocks at Mr Brown’s garden door. Mr Brown is surprised to see her, he stands.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: You once said you would offer what comfort you could.

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: Yes, of course, come in.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Is there something, anything at all you can read me from his letters? I am disappointed to have none of my own. Any sort of news, even the painful, brings me closer.

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: The latest letters are all from Severn. Keats I'm afraid, is in a deplorable state. Mr Brown sorts through his correspondence. MR BROWN (cont'd) I have some older ones from Keats.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: “I can bear to die - I cannot bear to leave her. Oh, God! God! God! Every thing I have in my trunks that reminds me of her goes through me like a spear.” Mr Brown looks up to judge Fanny’s reaction. She is not shocked but transported. MR BROWN (cont'd) “The silk lining she put in my travelling cap scalds my head. My imagination is horribly vivid about her - I see her - I hear her. O that I could be buried near where she lives! I am afraid to write to her - to receive a letter from her - to see her hand writing would break my heart. My dear Brown, what am I to do? Where can I look for consolation or ease? I have coals of fire in my breast. It surprised me that the human heart is capable of containing and bearing so much misery. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 156 157 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 91. MR BROWN (cont'd) Was I born for this end? God bless her, and her mother.” The letter is to me but it is all about you - keep it. Fanny shakes her head. They look at each other with something like peace, like compassion, for what they both and for what they must soon bear. Fanny turns and Mr Brown watches as Fanny’s ghostlike fig disappears down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the last of the light, Brown walks through the MUD SPLATTERED SNOW towards home.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. BRAWNE DRAWING ROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE
dialogues.text: Fanny and her mother sew while Samuel practices his VIOLI and Margaret plays happily with the CAT on the couch. The FRONT DOOR OPENING and CLOSING, then FOOTSTEPS in the hall outside attracts Fanny’s attention. She turns toward the door, poised. Mrs Brawne notices and watches the door anxiously. Samuel stops playing as a sombre Mr Brown ente the room. Fanny observes Mr Brown sinkingly, her breath suspended.

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: It is cold out. How are you all? Fanny notices a letter from Mr Severn in Mr Brown’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: We are all quite well enough. But how is Mr Keats?

dialogues.speaker: MR BROWN
dialogues.text: It is as unbearable to me as I know it is to you. Mr Keats has died at only 25 years. Mr Severn sent me an account, I have copied it for you Miss Brawne - shall I read it? Fanny nods. MR BROWN (cont'd) Friday 23rd February. “At four in the afternoon, Keats called me “Severn - Severn - lift me up for I am dying - I shall die easy - don’t be frightened, thank God it has come.” At one point a cold, heavy sweat broke out over his whole body and he whispered “Don’t breathe on me it comes like ice.” Keats died imperceptibly...  158 159 160 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 92.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY
dialogues.text: No more. Mr Brown stops reading. Fanny makes her way shakily from the room. Mrs Brawne follows. Fanny collapses on the staircase. FANNY (cont’d) I should have been with him. I should have held him - it should have been me with him. Oh my God I am finished. He is gone. Oh Maman help me, please help me. Mr Brown and Samuel listen stricken. Margaret sits on the couch, tears dropping onto her frock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small funeral procession of TWO COACHES waits by the PI BERNINI FOUNTAIN at the bottom of the SPANISH STEPS. Keat COFFIN is loaded into a BLACK FUNERAL COACH. The small procession clatters through Rome’s still sleeping streets

dialogues.speaker: KEATS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “'Lamia!’ he cried - and no soft-toned reply. The many heard, and the loud revelry Grew hush; the stately music no more breathes; The myrtle sicken’d in a thousand wreaths. By faint degrees, voice, lute, and pleasure ceased; A deadly silence step by step increased Until it seem’d a horrid presence there, And not a man but felt the terror in his hair.” INT. FANNY’S BEDROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - DAWN 160 In the DIM FIRST LIGHT an exhausted Fanny is sewing her B FROCK. She makes a KNOT and CUTS the thread. Across the b are strewn KEATS'S POETRY BOOKS and his LETTERS. In the next bed sleeps Margaret, her arms about her mother’s nec who sleeps fully dressed. Fanny pulls the BLACK FROCK ove her head, one sleeve yet unmade and the hem unfinished.  161 162 163 BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 93. INT. FANNY’S BEDROOM WENTWORTH HOUSE - DAWN 161 With three chops of her big PINKING SHEARS Fanny cuts her hair short. Her BLACK HAIR falls in a circle about her fe She takes her RED BOUND BOOK of Keats’s poems 1820, her c of ENDYMION and quietly leaves the room with her BONNET a BLACK BOOTS in her hand. Mrs Brawne rises as she leaves.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BRAWNE
dialogues.text: Samuel! Sammy!

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. BRAWNE FRONT DOOR WENTWORTH HOUSE
dialogues.text: Fanny draws on her COAT and BLACK GLOVES. She opens the f door and steps into the chilled and misty air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out on the Heath Fanny walks briskly through the winter M followed at a respectful distance by a hurriedly dressed Samuel. Fanny, the landscape, the trees, Samuel APPEARING and VANISHING in the FOG. Clutching her precious KEATS BO against her chest, Fanny makes her way up the side of the HILL where she and the landscape completely disappear, on her VOICE continues steadily reciting, learning by heart poem BRIGHT STAR dedicated to her.

dialogues.speaker: FANNY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “Bright Star, would I were stedfast as thou art - Not in lone splendour hung aloft the night And watching, with eternal lids apart, Like nature’s patient, sleepless Eremite, (devotee) The moving waters at their priest like task Of pure ablution round earth’s human shores, Or gazing on the new soft-fallen masque Of snow upon the mountains and the moors. No - yet still stedfast, still unchangeable, Pillow’d upon my fair love’s ripening breast, To feel forever its soft swell and fall, Awake forever in a sweet unrest, Still, still to hear her tender-taken breath, And so live ever - or else swoon to death.” Fanny now alone, walks on the Heath until in the dark she pauses beside the POND. Overhead the STARS GLITTER and ar REFLECTED again at her feet. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For three years Fanny Brawne continued to walk Hampstead Heath, often far into the night.  BLUE PAGES 04/04/08 94. Keats died imagining himself forgotten. Yet generation af generation of poets have been inspired by him, and his fa continues to grow.
